themes.title: Tang Dynasty and Cultural Exchange
points: Highlight the Tang dynasty as a period of cultural flourishing and innovation, setting the stage for later developments in Chinese ceramics and silk production.
Discuss the influence of Tang ceramics on neighboring regions like Korea, Japan, and Southeast Asia, emphasizing the spread of techniques and motifs.
Relate the Tang dynasty's global trade networks to the audience's interest in history, showcasing how Chinese goods like porcelain and silk reached the Middle East and Europe.

themes.title: Techniques and Symbolism in Ceramics
points: Explain the technical processes behind Jingdezhen porcelain, such as firing techniques and the use of cobalt blue for underglaze decoration.
Discuss the symbolism in designs, such as the lotus flower (purity), dragons (power and auspiciousness), and mandarin ducks (harmony and marriage).
Connect the audience's interest in techniques to the evolution of polychrome enamels like wucai and famille rose, highlighting their significance in Ming and Qing ceramics.

themes.title: Imperial Patronage and Exclusivity
points: Describe how certain ceramics, like the bowl with Xuande reign marks, were reserved for the imperial court and carried symbolic messages of power and respect.
Discuss the role of the imperial kilns in Jingdezhen and their production of high-quality wares for both domestic use and export.
Relate the exclusivity of imperial ceramics to the broader theme of cultural prestige and the global fascination with Chinese goods.

themes.title: Global Trade and Adaptation
points: Explore how Chinese ceramics influenced European production, such as Delftware and Meissen porcelain, and how European designs were incorporated into Chinese export wares.
Discuss the role of merchants and trade routes in spreading Chinese ceramics, including the Dutch East India Company and the Silk Road.
Highlight examples like the kraak-style plate and mounted jars, showing how Chinese designs were adapted for European tastes.

themes.title: Hands-On Engagement and Technology
points: Encourage students to examine the intricate designs on ceramics, identifying recurring motifs like floral patterns and mythical creatures.
Relate the precision and craftsmanship of ceramic production to computational concepts, such as pattern recognition and algorithmic design.
Discuss the technological advancements in firing techniques and material composition, drawing parallels to modern engineering and materials science.
